docs.lead_paragraph: In an advance that speeds up diagnosis of the most dangerous avian flu, scientists have developed a detailed influenza test that takes less than 12 hours, federal health officials said yesterday. The new technology, a microchip covered with bits of genetic material from many different flu strains, cuts the typical time needed for diagnosis of the A(H5N1) flu to less than a day from a week or more. In addition, rather than giving just a yes-or-no result, it usually reveals which flu a human or an animal has.

headline.main: New Test Speeds Diagnosis Of Lethal Avian Flu Strain

docs.abstract: Scientists develop detailed influenza test that takes less than 12 hours to diagnose dangerous avian flu; old test took a week or more; new technology makes it possible for public health officials investigating outbreak in poultry or humans to decide quickly whether to kill thousands of birds or treat hundreds of potentially exposed people with antiviral drugs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Condoms Stay Faithful When Prevention Is the Goal'' (Personal Health, Aug. 22): This column does not mention female condoms, which have been available for years, and it implies that there is only one kind of condom (for males). The omission is baffling and suggests a social taboo. Female condoms give control to women and help them avoid pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases, including herpes and H.I.V. An article on why this innovation is diffusing so slowly would be truly interesting. Ruta Sevo Fairfax, Va.
docs.abstract: Ruta Sevo letter on Jane E Brody August 22 Personal Health column questions why used of female condom was not mentioned in article

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Can a blood cancer be spread to a fetus during pregnancy or to another person by a blood transfusion? A. ''There are reports of cancer being transmitted from mother to fetus, but they are extremely rare,'' said Dr. John P. Leonard, clinical director of the Center for Lymphoma and Myeloma at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital in Manhattan. ''Most reports of transmission involve the transfer of cancer cells to the placenta rather than to the fetus itself.''
docs.abstract: Q & A column discusses potential of infecting others with blood cancer either through giving birth or blood transfusion; drawing (M)
